chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Quick, quick recap of what we did last time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So last time we introduced this idea

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of decomposition and abstraction.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we started putting that into our programs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these were sort of high level concepts.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we achieved them using these concrete things called

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: functions in our programs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And functions allowed us to create code that was coherent,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that had some structure to it, and was reusable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And from now on, in problem sets and in lectures,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to be using functions a lot.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So make sure that you understand how they work

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and all of those details.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So today we're going to introduce two new data types.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they're called compound data types

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because they're actually data types that are made up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of other data types, particularly

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: ints, floats, booleans, and strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And actually not just these, but other data types as well.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's why they're called compound data types.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're going to look at a new data type called a tuple

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and a new data type called a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we're going to talk about these ideas that come

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: about specifically with lists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, so let's go right into tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if you recall strings, strings

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: were sequences of characters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Tuples are going to be similar to strings

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in that they're going to be sequences of something.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Except that tuples aren't just sequences of characters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They can be sequences of anything.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They're a collection of data where

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that data can be of any type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So a tuple can contain elements that are integers, floats,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: strings, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Tuples are immutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if you recall, we talked about this word a little bit

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when we talked about strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that means once you create a tuple object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can't modify it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just like when you created a string object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you were not allowed to modify it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the way we create tuples are with these open and closed

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: parentheses.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This shouldn't be confused with a function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because this isn't a function call.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's just how you represent a tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For a function call, you'd have something right

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: before the parentheses.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is just how we chose to represent a tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And just a plain open and closed parentheses

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: represents an empty tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's of length 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There's nothing in it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can create a tuple that contains some elements

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: by separating each element with a comma.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this case, this is a tuple that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can be accessed with a variable t that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: contains three elements.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The first is an integer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The second is a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the third is another integer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Much like strings, we can index into tuples

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to find out values at particular indices.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you read this as t at position 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the tuple represented by variable t at position 0

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: will evaluate to 2 because, again, we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: start counting from 0 in computer science.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that gives us the first element.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Just like strings, we can concatenate tuples together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That just means add them together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if we add these two tuples together,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we just get back one larger tuple that's just those two.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The elements of those tuples just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: put together in one larger tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Again, much like strings, we can slice into tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So t slice from index 1 until index 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Remember, we go until this stop at minus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this only gives us one element inside the tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this is not a mistake.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This extra comma here actually represents a tuple object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I didn't have this comma here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then this would just be a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The parentheses wouldn't really make any difference.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But the comma here makes it clear to Python

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that this is a tuple with only one element in it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We can slice even further to get a tuple with two elements.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we can do the usual operations,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: like get the length of a tuple, which says,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how many elements are in my tuple?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And len of this t would evaluate to 3,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because there are three elements inside the tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Each element, again, separated by the comma.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And just like strings, if we try to change

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a value inside the tuple, in this case,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I wanted to try to change the value of the second element

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python doesn't allow that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because tuples are immutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So why would we want to use tuples?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Tuples are actually useful in a couple of different scenarios.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So recall, a few lectures ago, we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: looked at this code where we tried

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to swap the values of variables x and y.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this first code actually didn't work,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because you're overwriting the value for x.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So instead, what we ended up doing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was creating this temporary variable, where

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we stored the value of x, and then we overwrote it,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then we use the temporary variable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, it turns out this three-liner code right here

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can actually be written in one line using tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you say x comma y is equal to y comma x.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And Python goes in and says, what's the value of y,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and assigns it to x?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then what's the value of x and assigns it to y?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Extending on that, we can actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: use tuples to return more than one value from a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So functions, you're only allowed to return one object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're not allowed to return more than one object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: However, if we use a tuple object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and if that's the thing that we return,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we can actually get around this sort of rule

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: by putting in as many values as we want inside the tuple object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we can return as many values as we'd like.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this specific example, I'm trying

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to calculate the quotient and remainder

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when we divide x by y.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is a function definition here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And down here, I'm calling the function with 4 and 5.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when I make the function call,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: 4 gets assigned to x, and 5 gets assigned to y.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So then q is going to be the integer division

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when x is divided by y.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this double slash just means it's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: like casting the result to an integer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It says divide it, keep the whole number part,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and just delete everything else beyond the decimal point.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when you divide 4 by 5, this q is actually going to be 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's 0 point something, and I don't care about the point

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: something.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then the remainder is just using the percent operator.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when I divide 4 by 5, the remainder is going to be 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And notice that I'm going to be returning q and r, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are these two values that I calculated inside my function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm returning them in the context of this tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm only returning one object, which is a tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It just so happens that I'm populating that object

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with a few different values.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when the function returns here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: this is going to say 0, 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's the tuple it's going to return.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: q is going to be 0, and r is going to be 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So then this line here, quote, rem equals 0, 4,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is basically this little, it's sort of like what we did up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it assigns quote to 0 and rem to 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we can use tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is very useful.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We can use them to return more than one value from a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So tuples are great.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It might seem a little bit confusing at first,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but they're actually pretty useful,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because they hold collections of data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here I wrote a function, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I can apply to any set of data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'll explain what this function does,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then we can apply it to some data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can see that you can extract

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: some very basic information from whatever set of data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you happen to collect.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here's a function called getData,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it does all of this stuff in here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in the actual code associated with the lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I actually said what the condition on a tuple was.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it has to be a tuple that looks a certain way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this is the way that it has to look.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's one tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The outer parentheses out here represent the fact

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that it's a tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the elements of this tuple are actually other tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the first element's a tuple object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the second element's a tuple object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and third one's a tuple object, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And each one of these inner tuple objects

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are actually going to contain two elements, the first being

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: an integer and the second being a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's sort of the precondition

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that this function assumes on a tuple

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: before it actually can work.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, so given a tuple that looks like that,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what's the function going to do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's first creating two empty tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One is called nums and one is called words.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then there's a for loop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And notice here, the for loop is

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to iterate over every element inside the tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Remember in strings when we were able to use

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for loops that iterated over the characters directly as opposed

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: over the indices?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, we're doing the same sort of thing here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Instead of iterating over the indices,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're going to iterate over the tuple object at each position.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So first time through the loop, t here

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is going to be this first tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The second time through the loop, t

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is going to be this tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the third time, it's going to be this exact tuple object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So each time through the loop, what I'm doing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is I'm going to have this nums tuple that I'm

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to keep adding to.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And each time, I'm going to create a new object

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and reassign it to this variable nums.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And each time through the loop, I'm looking at what

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the previous value of nums was.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what was my previous tuple?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm going to add it with this singleton tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's a tuple of one character or one element, this element

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: being t at position 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you have to sort of wrap your mind around

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how this is working.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if t is going to be this tuple element right here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then t at position 0 is going to be this blue bar here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it represents the integer portion of the tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So as we're going through the loop,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: this nums is going to get populated

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with all of the integers from every one of my tuple,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: inside tuple objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's basically what this line here is doing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: At the same time, I'm also populating this words tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the words tuple is a little bit different

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because I'm not adding every single one of these string

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: objects, so t at position 1 being the string

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: part of the inner tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm actually adding the string part only if it's not already

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in my words list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here, I'm essentially grabbing all

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the unique strings from my list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: These last three lines, three, four lines here just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: do a little bit of arithmetic on it, saying, OK, now I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: have all of the numbers here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What's the minimum out of all of these?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then what's the maximum out of all of these?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then this unique words variable

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: tells me how many unique words do I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: have in my original tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this feels sort of generic, so let's run it on some data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here, I tested it on some test data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I got some actual data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this actual data that I wanted to analyze

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was Taylor Swift data, and representing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the integer portion of the tuple representing a year,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and the string portion of the tuple representing the person

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: who she wrote a song about that year.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So some real world data that we're working with here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Very important that we know this information.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So with this data, I can run it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I can plug it into this function that I wrote up here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm going to actually comment this out

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: so it doesn't get cluttered.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if I run it, this is the part

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where I'm calling my function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm calling it with this data here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: T-Swift being this tuple of tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And what I get back is up here, line 38,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is the return from the function being a large tuple.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that large tuple, I'm then assigning it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to my own tuple in my program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I'm just printing out some statement here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm getting the minimum year, the maximum year, and then

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the number of people.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I can show you that it works if I replace

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: one of these names with another one that I already have in here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So instead of writing a song about five people,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: she would have wrote a song about four people.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yay, it worked.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And remember, or recall, keep in mind tuples were immutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now we're going to look at a very, very similar data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: structure to tuples called lists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Except that instead of lists being immutable,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: lists are going to be mutable objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So much like lists, they're going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to contain elements of any type or objects of any type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You denote a list with square brackets instead of parentheses.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the difference being that they're

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to be mutable objects instead of immutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So creating an empty list, you just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: do open, close square brackets.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can have a list of elements of different types.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Even a list of lists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So one of the elements being a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: As usual, you can apply length on a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that tells you how many elements are in it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is going to tell you how many elements

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are in your list L. So it's not going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to look any further than that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's going to say, this is an integer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is an integer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is a list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's not going to say how many elements are in this list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's just going to look at the outer shell of elements.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Indexing and slicing works the same way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So L at position 0 gives you the value 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can index into a list and then do something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with the value that you get back.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So L at position 2 says, that's this value there,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and add 1 to it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: L at position 3, that's going to be this list here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Notice it evaluates to another list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You're not allowed to index outside

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the length of the list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's going to give you an error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because we only have four elements.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can also have expressions for your index.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this Python just replaces i with 2 here and says,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what's L at position 1?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it grabs that from in there.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So very, very similar to the kinds of operations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we've seen on strings and tuples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The one difference, and that's what

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're going to focus on for the rest of this class,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is that lists are mutable objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what does that mean internally?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Internally, that means, let's say we have a variable L that's

chunks.title: Lecture
